newsitem.title: DENMARK: Danes to keep fighting German shipbuilding aid.
newsitem.headline: Danes to keep fighting German shipbuilding aid.

text.p: Danish shipbuilders on Tuesday vowed to continue their fight against German government aid to its shipbuilders despite a European Court ruling against them.

"We intend to study the text of the ruling in detail, there is a lot in it which we can use in our ongoing battle against state subsidies in the shipbuilding industry," Danish Shipbuilders' Association chief Thorkild Christensen told the Danish news agency Ritzau.
The court earlier dismissed an appeal by the association against the European Commission's approval of state aid for Germany's Meerestechnik Werft Shipyard Wismar (MTW).

The Danish shipbuilders filed suit against the Commission's May 1994 decision to clear the release of a second tranche of German state aid totalling 406 million marks ($264.9 million) to the German yard.
Christensen said that the court ruling emphasised that it allowed the aid only because of "very special circumstances".
"The ruling clearly establishes the fact that MTW is still subject to production restrictions and we reckon that this must also apply to other German shipyards," he said.
Denmark, its shipbuilding industry hit by its strong crown, spiralling costs, and competition from Asian yards, opposes state subsidies.

"The Commission states that any increase in (German) production would be in violation of the rules. Germany had wanted to give a further four billion crowns in aid to shipyards in Wismar and Stralsund. It is our task now to ensure that no more 'very special circumstances' occur," Christensen said.
The Association, supported by the Danish government, had wanted the Commission's clearance decision to be annulled "in part or in its entirety."
